- I'm Catherine, I'm a full-stack developer (whatever that means). - I use she/her pronouns. - I work at a small webshop in Ohio, Sparkbox. - I spent most of my last couple years building a single enterprise-level design system. - The past few weeks I've been doing more JavaScript-based work, along with some Docker chores and accessibility improvements. - One thing never changes, though. ‚ÄúGiving positive feedback is an easy habit to adopt. You're already reading through the lines of code, looking for issues. It doesn't take much time to throw in a ‚ÄòNice!‚Äô or ‚ÄòLooks great!‚Äô If you see something awesome, say it!‚Äù
- Bryan Braun
tiny.cc/foundry-braun
* This is really difficult for me. My Meyers-Briggs type is a INTJ. Famous INTJs are such lovable characters, like Minecroft from Sherlock, Walter White from Breaking Bad, and Littlefinger from Game of Thrones. We're not nice by default. We can be a little direct. * Sometimes positive feedback feels fake, but that's okay. It won't read that way. * I really like leading zeros on decimal points in CSS. In any language, I enjoy descriptive comments. I am always complimenting these things, and it may feel forced, but it is honest. * A few positive comments make a huge difference in overall tone of a review, whether you are speaking with developers, designers, or other team contributors.
Thanks!

Catherine Meade

* Hopefully at least one of these tools can make the PR experience more accessible for your whole team‚Äînot just the developers. * With a healthy dose of empathy, we can improve the way our coworkers review the code we write, and as a result, we can create smoother workflows, increase both speed and communication, and make better websites.
